questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, mild abdominal distention, and constipation. On physical examination, there was notable tenderness near the navel. The physician immediately orders some tests, but none of it turns out satisfactory. Hence, after giving initial medications to the child, the physician orders a Meckel's scan to check for Meckel’s diverticulum. Which of the following is true about Meckel’s diverticulum?

options.label: A
options.text: Is found in about 4% of the population.

options.label: B
options.text: Is always found on the antimesenteric border of the ileum.

options.label: C
options.text: Is usually about 2 cm in length.

options.label: D
options.text: Is usually located about 20 cm from the ileocaecal junction.

questions.correct_answer: B. Is always found on the antimesenteric border of the ileum.

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant presents with worsening respiratory distress for 3 days. What statements are true regarding the involved structure?

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn baby presents to the physician with complaints of complete loss of breath and turning blue on several occasions. His breathing improves if the baby is placed in an upright or sitting position. Physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the baby is lying down. On auscultation, there are no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A surgeon has exposed the operative field for a cardio-thoracic procedure for a case of apical lung cancer and identified a few nerves in the region. Injury to which of the marked nerves in the diagram may affect respiratory movements?

A 31-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and dysfunction of his right arm following a previous radial bone fracture from a road traffic accident. X-ray shows healed fracture with decreased width and atrophy of the right arm. The symptoms are likely due to compression of neurovascular bundles passing through which structure?

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are correct

questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Both A and B

questions.text: Which of the following statements is/are true about the brachial plexus? A. Lower trunk is formed by root C8 and T1 B. Lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk C. Posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks D. Anterior division of the lower trunk continuous as medial cord and give rise to the radial nerve.

What's incorrect about the blood vessel causing left arm weakness, numbness, and low blood pressure compared to the right arm in a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and previous myocardial infarction?

options.label: A
options.text: On the left side arises from the arch of the aorta

options.label: B
options.text: On the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk

options.label: C
options.text: Vertebral artery arises from 2 nd part of the subclavian artery

options.label: D
options.text: Divided by scalenus anterior muscle into three parts

questions.correct_answer: C. Vertebral artery arises from 2 nd part of the subclavian artery

The Xth cranial nerve involvement is suspected. Which of the following muscles' actions cannot confirm this involvement through testing?

He has a history of recent hip replacement surgery and immobilization. CT angiography reveals a filling defect in the right pulmonary artery. Which tributary of the IVC is most likely associated with the formation of pulmonary embolism?

questions.text: During embryonic development, the ventral mesogastrium gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Derivative of Mesogastrium Organs/Body Parts Formed or Originated Duration Trimester Other Important Points
Greater omentum Adipose tissue, connective tissue Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, hangs down from greater curvature of stomach, forms a double-layered fold of peritoneum, may become thickened in pathological conditions
Lesser omentum Hepatoduodenal ligament, hepatogastric ligament Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from ventral mesogastrium, connects liver and duodenum/stomach, contains blood vessels and lymphatics supplying these organs
Falciform ligament Connects liver to anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from ventral mesogastrium, suspends liver from anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm
Splenorenal ligament Connects spleen to posterior abdominal wall Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, suspends spleen from posterior abdominal wall
Transverse mesocolon Supports transverse colon Week 8-10 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, forms a fold of peritoneum that suspends transverse colon
Mesentery Supports small intestines Week 6-10 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, contains blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves supplying small intestines
Gastrosplenic ligament Connects stomach to spleen Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, suspends stomach from spleen
Gastrophrenic ligament Connects stomach to diaphragm Week 4-8 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, suspends stomach from diaphragm
Gastrocolic ligament Connects stomach to transverse colon Week 8-10 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, forms a fold of peritoneum that connects stomach to transverse colon
Phrenicocolic ligament Connects diaphragm to transverse colon Week 8-10 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, connects diaphragm to transverse colon
Hepatocolic ligament Connects liver to transverse colon Week 8-10 1st trimester Derived from ventral mesogastrium, connects liver to transverse colon
Rectal mesocolon Supports rectum Week 10-12 1st trimester Derived from dorsal mesogastrium, forms a fold of peritoneum that supports rectum

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe burning pain, tingling, and numbness in her right hand and fingers. The pain is aggravated by movement and has been persistent for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals decreased sensation in the affected hand. Which of the following structures is most likely involved?

options.label: D
options.text: Gray matter of C6 spinal cord segment

questions.correct_answer: A. Dorsal root ganglion of C6
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Location

Along the dorsal roots of spinal nerves

Origin

Arise from neural crest cells during embryonic development

Type

Composed of cell bodies of sensory neurons

Branches

Give rise to dorsal root (enters spinal cord) and ventral root (exits spinal cord)

Diseases/Disorders

Herpes zoster, sensory neuronopathies, ganglionopathy, tumors

Parts

Cell bodies of sensory neurons, satellite cells, nerve fibers

Symptoms if Damaged

Sensory deficits: numbness, tingling, pain

Treatment for special disorders

Depends on underlying condition (e.g., antiviral meds for herpes zoster, immunosuppressive therapy for autoimmune sensory neuronopathies, surgery for tumors)

Functions

Transmit sensory information from periphery to spinal cord

Anatomy

Located outside spinal cord, contains pseudounipolar neurons

Connectivity

Synapse with interneurons or motor neurons in spinal cord

Development

Arise from neural crest cells during embryonic development

Clinical Presentation

Sensory deficits in corresponding dermatomes

Diagnostic Tests

Electromyography (EMG), nerve conduction studies, imaging (MRI, CT)

Extra Info

Part of PNS, transmit sensory information, treatment depends on underlying condition
 

Distribution of Large and Small Dorsal Root Ganglion Neurons

questions.text: According to Couinaud's classification, which hepatic segment is located between the middle hepatic vein and the left hepatic vein?
questions.explanation:
The 08 Segments of Couinaud's Classification
Liver Segment Couinaud's Segment Vascular Supply Bile Drainage Clinical Significance
Segment I Caudate lobe Hepatic artery Right lobe Surgical resection of tumors, bile duct reconstruction
Segment II Left lateral Hepatic artery Left lobe Liver transplantation, resection of tumors near the left liver margin
Segment III Left medial Hepatic artery Left lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the middle hepatic vein
Segment IVa Left anterior Hepatic artery Left lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the left portal vein and left hepatic artery
Segment IVb Left posterior Hepatic artery Left lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the left portal vein and right hepatic artery
Segment V Left posterior Portal vein Left lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the left portal vein
Segment VI Right anterior Portal vein Right lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the right portal vein
Segment VII Right posterior Portal vein Right lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the right portal vein
Segment VIII Right superior Portal vein Right lobe Liver resection, tumors involving the right portal vein

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant has been brought by his parents to the pediatrician's office concerning his dysmorphic features. He has a flat facial appearance, a small head, prominent epicanthic folds, a flat nasal bridge, a protruding tongue with an open mouth, hypotonia, and a pansystolic murmur. He was born to a 36-year-old mother after a normal gestation and delivery. His parents' karyotypes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely syndrome according to this karyotype?

A 5-year-old boy presents with decreased urinary output, brown colour urine, decreased appetite, nausea, and fatigue for the last 3 days. On examination, significant findings are anaemia, mild pedal oedema and mild facial puffiness. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, while the other vitals are normal. On his urine analysis, the following lab findings are found: Urine Output Less than 300mls/day Blood +++ Red cell casts 100/hpf Protein Less than 3.5g/L/day What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Glomerular syndromes

  

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome

Hematuria/RBC casts

Hypoalbuminemia

Oliguria

Oedema

Hypertension

Hyperlipidemia

Decreased GFR

Lipiduria

Proteinuria +/-

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with an unstable gait. His mother complains t hat the boy staggers while walking, and it is difficult for him to climb stairs. He also has droopy eyelids. When asked to release his hand after making a handgrip, he has difficulty opening his grip . The image of the child is given below. Identify the disease this child is suffering from:

A 10-year-old boy presents in the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine, lower abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 2 days. There is no history of decreased urine output. On examination, the patient's vitals are normal except for having tachycardia (102 beats/minute). He is mildly dehydrated and has evidence of dermatitis herpetiformis . Urine analysis shows evidence of gross haematuria. C3 levels are normal, and peripheral smear examination also shows no remarkable findings. Wh ich of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old female presents with a history of developmental delay, loss of previously acquired milestones, and hand wringing. On examination, she has microcephaly and a wide-based gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with recurrent infections and easy bruising. On examination, he has partial albinism and nystagmus. Laboratory tests show neutropenia and impaired phagocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A newborn presents with a non-blanching rash and bleeding from the gums and nose. The mother has a history of lupus and positive antiphospholipid antibodies. Which complication of neonatal lupus should be suspected?

A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, left lower lobe crepitation is heard. A diagnosis of pneumonia is made. Pneumonia is an acute lung parenchymal infection. The protective response is the invasion of neutrophils at the area of infection. A process known as NETosis is involved during the whole event of inflammation. Which of the following is least likely associated with the process of "NETosis"?

options.label: C

questions.text: A 37-years-old female is admitted to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing . Examination reveals significant laryngeal edema . Past medical history indicates that she suffers from recurrent episodes of angioneurotic edema with the release of histamine and other mediators. Which of the following statement related to the given mediator of acute inflammation is correct?

options.text: Histamine H2 receptor antagonists are used to treat allergies

questions.correct_answer: A. Antibodies and complement products bind to specific mast cell receptors and trigger signalling pathways that induce degranulation to release histamine

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented in the medical outpatient department with a complaint of brief and abrupt unintentional, chaotic movements of hands and legs for the last 5 months. There is also a history of sustained and prolonged abnormal neck posture, declining cognitive function, and thinking ability. Her father was also diagnosed with a condition based on similar symptoms. She is vitally stable, and physical examination shows choreiform movements of all limbs and nystagmus. A plain MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the caudate nucleus. She is diagnosed with a genetic disorder that does not follow Mendelian inheritance. Which of the following is the possible diagnosis?

A 15-year-old girl presented to the physician's office complaining of sore throat, fever and fatigue for the past few days . On physical examination, the tonsils have erythema and white exudate and are bilaterally enlarged . After further testing, the virus was identified. This virus also uses the LMP-1 gene for inducing oncogenesis . Which of the following virus is responsible for the disease ?
questions.explanation:
Virus

Gene

  • Tax gene
  • Hepatitis B virus
  • HBx gene
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • LMP-1 gene

  • E6 and E7 proteins

questions.text: You are an intern in the obstetrics & gynaecology department; you receive a case of term teenage pregnancy in labor with cephalopelvic disproportion. Your resident doctor instructs you to get the blood investigations done ready as the patient is to be taken for an emergency lower segment cesarian section (LSCS) procedure, especially since the resident asked u to get the blood grouping and Rh typing done first. Which of the following potentially represents the most dangerous situation?
questions.correct_answer: B. Rh-ve mother with 2nd Rh+ve child
questions.explanation:
Erythroblastosis fetalis
  • It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which antigenic difference between the mother and the fetus, and IgG anti-erythrocyte antibodies from the mother cross the placenta and cause destruction of fetal red cells.
  • First Rh +ve child of a Rh –ve mother is at very low risk of developing erythroblastosis fetalis, because foetal Rh+ cells pass to the maternal circulation and trigger anti Rh+ antibodies.
  • In second pregnancy, if the foetus is Rh+, the sensitized anti Rh+ antibodies pass through placenta and trigger hemolytic disease of newborn.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a complaint of increased hunger, increased thirst, and increased urination. Blood and urine glucose tests are suggestive of diabetes. The physician suspects type I diabetes in this patient, which is caused by T-cell mediated destruction of Islets of Langerhans cells. Which of the following is/are an example of type IV hypersensitivity?
questions.explanation:
Examples of Type IV hypersensitivity (T cell mediated hypersensitivity) reactions
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Psoriasis
  • Contact sensitivity

questions.text: A 48-Year-old male, a chronic alcoholic, presents to the hospital with sudden onset fever, chills, and rigour. He underwent a liver transplant 2 weeks ago after developing liver cirrhosis and fulminant hepatic failure . His heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and SpO 2 is 87%. All of the following regarding the condition described above is true, except?

options.label: A
options.text: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft

options.label: B
options.text: It is the principal cause of early graft failure

options.label: C
options.text: Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor

options.label: D
options.text: Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

questions.correct_answer: C. Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to an outpatient clinic with a six-month history of shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 85/minute. On the X-ray of the chest, there is evidence of hilar lymphadenopathy. The biopsy revealed the presence of non-caseating granulomas . Lab results show hypercalcemia. Which of the following pathogenic mechanisms is involved in sarcoidosis development?

options.label: A
options.text: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD8+ T cells

options.label: B
options.text: Increased levels of T cell-derived TH1 cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased levels of cytokines in the local environment IL-8, TNF

options.text: Decreased the level of ACE enzyme

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency room with progressive atrophy and weakness in his hands. On further examination, he is found to have brisk jaw jerk, fasciculations, spasticity of the lower leg and bulbar palsy. He is diagnosed with a case of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is caused by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.

options.text: Loss of dopaminergic neurons from the substantia nigra

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
questions.explanation:
Upper motor neurons lesion Lower motor neuron lesion
Pyramidal & Extrapyramidal tracts involved Motor neurons of the spinal cord & Neurons of cranial nerve nuclei are involved
Group of Muscle affected Single Muscle affected
Tone - ↑ Lost
Power – Normal or no loss Lost
Superficial & deep reflexes lost Lost
Babinski’s sign present Absent
Clonus present Absent
Clasp knife reflex present Absent
Spasticity Absent

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with his wife, complaining that her husband has not "been himself lately." A researcher is asked to investigate the truth about an idea proposed by one of her peers. The research topic is the absolute refractory period. His peer has proposed a strong assertion and has given reason to support it. Assertion A . A second action potential cannot be elicited during the absolute refractory period, even with a strong stimulus. Reason B . The researcher investigates the claim and makes a statement regarding assertion and reason based on previous research on the subject. What could be the correct option?

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the reason is independently a false/incorrect statement.

options.label: D
options.text: The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.correct_answer: C. The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the reason is independently a false/incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath for five hours. The patient is diaphoretic. His pulse is 210 bpm, BP 120/85 mmHg, and saturation is 95% at room air. There is no sign of clubbing or oedema on physical examination. The histopathologic examination of the heart on autopsy reveals the accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway. Which among the following fibres are the most rapidly depolarising fibres in the ventricles of the heart?

options.label: B

Which of the following statements about the structure of the cytoskeleton is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The cytoskeleton is composed of three types of fibers: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.

options.label: B
options.text: Microfilaments are the largest type of cytoskeletal fibers and provide support for the cell.

options.label: C
options.text: Intermediate filaments are responsible for cell motility and contraction.

options.label: D
options.text: Microtubules are made up of the protein actin and are important in the formation of cell-cell junctions.

questions.correct_answer: A. The cytoskeleton is composed of three types of fibers: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.
questions.explanation:
Function Description
Maintains cell shape The cytoskeleton provides mechanical support and maintains the shape of the cell.
Cell motility Enables cell motility, including the movement of cells during embryonic development, wound healing, and immune responses.
Intracellular transport Plays a role in intracellular transport, such as moving organelles and vesicles around the cell.
Cell division Involved in cell division, including the separation of chromosomes during mitosis and the formation of the contractile ring during cytokinesis.
Cell signaling Facilitate cell signaling by serving as a scaffold for signaling molecules, and by participating in the activation and regulation of signaling pathways.
Mechanical sensing Sense mechanical forces and transduce them into biochemical signals that influence cell behavior, such as changes in gene expression or cell migration.
Organizing cellular components Organizes cellular components, such as forming the axoneme in cilia and flagella, and the microvilli in intestinal epithelial cells.

Gastroileal reflexes Reflexes that stimulate ileal motility in response to gastric distension Stomach and ileum Ileocecal valve relaxation

questions.correct_answer: A. MMCs help mix and propel chyme through the small intestine
questions.explanation:
Phase Characteristics
Phase I Lasts 60-90 minutes, occurs during fasting state, low amplitude contractions
Phase II Lasts 10-20 minutes, intermittent and irregular contractions increase in amplitude and frequency
Phase III Lasts 5-15 minutes, regular and intense contractions sweep down the small intestine, clears remaining contents
Phase IV Brief period, no contractions, returns to Phase I

Factors affecting MMCs function Regulation of MMCs
Gastrointestinal hormones (e.g., motilin, ghrelin) Stimulate MMCs and increase their frequency and amplitude.
Stress Increases sympathetic activity and decreases parasympathetic activity.
Prokinetic agents (e.g., erythromycin, metoclopramide) Enhance the function of MMCs and increase their frequency and amplitude.
Posture MMCs occur more frequently in the upright position compared to the supine position.
Inflammation Leads to delayed gastric emptying and intestinal transit.
Neural reflexes Such as the gastrocolic reflex, can modulate the activity of MMCs.

Drug Mechanism of Action Pharmacokinetics Indications Adverse Effects
Infliximab (Remicade) Binds to tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-α) to inhibit its action IV infusion, half-life: 8-10 days Rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriasis Infusion reactions, hypersensitivity reactions, immunosuppression, increased risk of infection, congestive heart failure, infusion-related reactions, hepatotoxicity, malignancies, others.
Rituximab (Rituxan) Targets CD20 antigen on B-cells, leading to cell lysis IV infusion, half-life: 22 days Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatoid arthritis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis Infusion reactions, hypersensitivity reactions, immunosuppression, increased risk of infection, cardiotoxicity, skin rash, gastrointestinal disturbances, hepatotoxicity, others.
Pembrolizumab (Keytruda) Blocks the PD-1 receptor on T-cells to enhance immune response against cancer cells IV infusion, half-life: 26 days Melanoma, non-small cell lung cancer, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, others Immune-related adverse events, infusion reactions, increased risk of infection, hypothyroidism, hepatotoxicity, pneumonitis, colitis, others.
Trastuzumab (Herceptin) Targets HER2/neu receptor on breast cancer cells, inhibiting cell growth IV infusion, half-life: 4-6 days HER2-positive breast cancer Infusion reactions, hypersensitivity reactions, cardiotoxicity, decreased left ventricular ejection fraction, increased risk of infection, gastrointestinal disturbances, others.
Bevacizumab (Avastin) Targets vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) to inhibit angiogenesis IV infusion, half-life: 20 days Colorectal cancer, lung cancer, glioblastoma, ovarian cancer, renal cell carcinoma Hypersensitivity reactions, immunosuppression, increased risk of bleeding, gastrointestinal perforation, wound healing complications, proteinuria, hypertension, others.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of renal impairment is prescribed probenecid for the treatment of gout. Which of the following precautions should be taken while administering probenecid in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pharmacology of Probenecid
Mechanism of Action Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules, increasing its excretion in urine.
ADME
  • Well absorbed orally
  • Widely distributed in tissues
  • Minimal hepatic metabolism
  • Primarily excreted unchanged in urine
Dose Usual adult dose for gout: 250 mg orally twice daily initially, then gradually increased to 500 mg to 2 g/day in divided doses.
Uses
  • Long-term management of gout by lowering serum uric acid levels
  • Adjunctive agent in the treatment of some viral infections such as herpes simplex and HIV
Adverse Effects
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Gastrointestinal discomfort
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
    • Rash
    • Fever
    • Anaphylaxis

To Remember: Caution in patients with renal impairment
Contraindications Known hypersensitivity to probenecid or sulfa-containing drugs; severe renal impairment or renal failure; history of uric acid kidney stones

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a severe allergic reaction, including rash, swelling, and difficulty breathing, after receiving amoxicillin for a suspected respiratory infection. His medical history is significant for a previous episode of an allergic reaction to penicillin. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinue amoxicillin and provide supportive care

questions.explanation:
Beta-lactam Allergy
Definition
  • Hypersensitivity reaction to beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and cephalosporins
Mechanism
  • Immune-mediated response, usually involving IgE antibodies
Clinical Manifestations
  • Can range from mild rash and itching to severe anaphylaxis with respiratory distress, hypotension, and shock
Risk Factors
  • Previous history of beta-lactam allergy, family history of drug allergies, history of other allergies (e.g., hay fever)
Management
  • Avoidance of beta-lactam antibiotics in patients with known allergy, use of alternative non-beta-lactam antibiotics, administration of epinephrine for severe allergic reactions
Cross-reactivity
  • Patients with penicillin allergy may have increased risk of cross-reactivity with cephalosporins, but the risk is generally low (1-5%)
Precautions
  • Careful evaluation of patient's allergy history before prescribing beta-lactam antibiotics, monitoring for allergic reactions during antibiotic therapy
Beta-lactam Antibiotic Management of Allergy Alternative Antibiotics and Doses
Penicillins
  • Avoid use in confirmed severe immediate hypersensitivity to penicillins.  
  • Consider alternative antibiotics.  
  • Desensitization may be considered in consultation with an allergist/ immunologist
  • Generally considered safe in penicillin allergy.  
  • May be used as an alternative in severe penicillin allergy.

 
Cephalosporins
  • Low risk of cross-reactivity with penicillin allergy.
  • Use with caution in severe penicillin allergy.  
  • Consider alternative antibiotics
Carbapenems
Monobactams
  • Generally considered safe in penicillin allergy.  
  • May be used as an alternative in severe penicillin allergy.

Aspect Summary
Classification
  • Beta-lactam antibiotics include penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems, and monobactams
Mechanism of Action
  • Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) and inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes
Spectrum of Activity
  • Broad spectrum against Gram-positive and some Gram-negative bacteria
Resistance Mechanisms
  • Production of beta-lactamases (enzymes that cleave the beta-lactam ring), alteration or loss of PBPs, efflux pumps
Common Examples
  • Penicillins (e.g., amoxicillin, ampicillin), cephalosporins (e.g., cefazolin, ceftriaxone), carbapenems (e.g., imipenem, meropenem), monobactams (e.g., aztreonam)
Adverse Effects
  • Allergic reactions (including rash, itching, anaphylaxis), gastrointestinal upset, drug interactions, superinfections (e.g., Clostridioides difficile infection)
Precautions
  • Careful evaluation of patient's allergy history before prescribing beta-lactam antibiotics, monitoring for adverse effects during antibiotic therapy, caution in patients with renal impairment, drug interactions with other medications

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes and a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection is started on Linezolid for treatment. After 3 days of therapy, the patient develops a sudden onset of weakness and dark-colored urine. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. What is the most likely side effect of Linezolid in this case?
questions.explanation:
Parameter Information
Drug Class Oxazolidinone antibiotic
Mechanism of Action Binds to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S subunit, inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis
Spectrum of Activity Gram-positive bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium (VRE)
Pharmacokinetics
  • Absorption: Oral bioavailability >90%
  • Distribution: Wide tissue distribution, including lung, skin, soft tissue, and bone
  • Metabolism: Minimal hepatic metabolism
  • Elimination: Primarily excreted unchanged in the urine (65-75%) and feces (30%)
Half-life Approximately 5-6 hours in adults
Adverse Drug Reactions
  • Myelosuppression (e.g., anemia, thrombocytopenia)
  • Peripheral neuropathy (with long-term use)
  • Serotonin syndrome (when used concomitantly with serotonergic drugs)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Rhabdomyolysis
Contraindications
  • Hypersensitivity to Linezolid or any component of the formulation
  • Concomitant use with or within 2 weeks of discontinuing monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)

Pharmacology of Chloramphenicol
Drug class Antibiotic
Mechanism of action Binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit of bacterial ribosomes, inhibiting protein synthesis
Pharmacokinetics
  • Absorbed orally
  • Widely distributed in tissues
  • Undergoes hepatic metabolism
  • Excreted primarily in urine
Dose and route Oral, intravenous, or topical administration; dosage varies depending on indication and patient age
Uses Treatment of serious bacterial infections caused by susceptible organisms, including meningitis and rickettsial infections
Adverse drug reactions
  • Bone marrow suppression
  • Gray baby syndrome in newborns/infants
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Drug fever
Contraindications
  • Hypersensitivity to Chloramphenicol
  • Pre-existing bone marrow suppression
  • Pregnancy (except in life-threatening situations)

questions.explanation:
Aspects Summary
Types of Medical Gas Pipeline Systems
  • Oxygen pipeline system
  • Nitrous oxide pipeline system
  • Medical air pipeline system
  • Vacuum pipeline system
  • Carbon dioxide pipeline system
  • Nitrogen pipeline system
Role of Anesthesiologist

Pressure and Flow

  • Medical air: around 50 psi
  • Vacuum: negative pressure
  • Carbon dioxide and nitrogen: varies with application
PSI Levels and Significance
  • PSI measures gas pressure
  • Different PSI levels indicate gas pressure
  • Proper monitoring and maintenance for patient safety
Safety Measures
  • Regular checks of equipment
  • Proper labeling of gas outlets
  • Back-up systems for emergencies
  • Compliance with policies and standards
Troubleshooting and Issue Management
  • Prompt identification and resolution of issues
  • Notifying maintenance teams
  • Adjusting flow rates or using alternative sources
Training and Education
  • Adequate training and education for anesthesiologists
  • Ongoing updates on policies and guidelines
Documentation and Record-keeping
  • Proper documentation of readings, checks, and actions
  • Accurate record-keeping for audit trails and patient safety
Gas Source and Storage
  • Centralized gas sources
  • Onsite storage and distribution systems
  • Backup and redundancy systems
Alarm Systems and Emergency Preparedness
  • Alarm systems for gas leaks and pressure drops
  • Emergency preparedness and response protocols
Regular Maintenance and Inspections
  • Regular maintenance and inspection of gas pipeline systems
  • Compliance with regulatory requirements
Standards and Guidelines
  • Compliance with national and international standards
  • Adherence to hospital and institutional guidelines

On examination, his skin is pale and clammy. He has a significant history of 10 pack years of smoking from the last 2 years. His breathing is rapid and shallow. Considering the above symptoms, what does the following barium swallow image demonstrate in this patient?

A 20-year-old female presents to the emergency department with right lower quadrant abdominal pain. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed. The imaging findings show a blind-ended tubular structure with an inner diameter of 8 mm, located in the right lower quadrant and surrounded by inflammatory changes. The most likely diagnosis is:

A 25-year-old male with a history of herpes simplex virus infection presents with fever, uneasiness, and joint pain for the past 2 days. On examination, his pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F). On examination of the skin, lesions are noted on the palms and back of his hands and feet, as shown below: Which of the following is likely a diagnosis of this patient’s skin lesions?

A 39-year-old male presents to the clinic due to discoloration of the right toenail for the past few months. He has a history of foot injury 6-months ago, which led to the separation of the right toenail from its nail bed. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin daily. Examination reveals thickening and darkening of the right toenail as shown in the image below: Which of the following is the most effective treatment in the management of this patient’s nail condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Debridement of the nail followed by systemic itraconazole

options.label: D
options.text: Removal of the nail followed by systemic amphotericin B

questions.correct_answer: C. Debridement of the nail followed by systemic itraconazole
questions.explanation:
Drugs Recommended Dosages
Terbinafine 250 mg/day for 6 and 12 weeks in fingernail and toenail onychomycosis, respectively.
Itraconazole

Pulse therapy:

200 mg twice daily for 1 week/month for 2 and 3 consecutive months for finger and toenail onychomycosis, respectively.

Continuous regimen:

200 mg/day for 6 weeks.
Fluconazole 150 mg weekly for a maximum period of 12 months

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of a nodule under the nail of her index finger. She states that the nodule is painful, and exposure to cold increases her pain. On examination, a small, round bluish nodule on her index nail bed is noted. Increased pinprick sensitivity is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Herpetic Whitlow Glomus Tumor Osteoma Subungual Hematoma
Herpes simplex virus infection Benign, vascular neoplasms arising from the glomus body. Benign bone tumor Injuries of the nail bed in which bleeding develops under the nail where blood is located between the nail matrix and nail plate.
Local tenderness, erythema, and edema with the initial crop of vesicles - along the pulp and lateral aspect of the finger. Vesicles usually coalesce into large, honeycomb-like bullae.

Two main clinical presentations of subungual glomus

tumor :

• A small reddish or bluish spot (<1 cm) seen through the nail

plate.

• A longitudinal erythronychia with distal notching or overlying

longitudinal fissure.

The classic triad of symptoms:

Hypersensitivity to cold

Heightened pinprick sensitivity

Paroxysmal pain

Small—less than 1.5 cm in size— cause the reactive bone to form around them.

Causes a dull, aching pain - moderate in intensity but can worsen and become severe—especially at night.		 The complaints of pain and discoloration of the nail - appear reddish, purple, brown, black, or a combination of these colors. The color variation is related to the duration and stage of healing.
It may involve the nail bed -hemorrhagic or purpuric lesions.

The pressure of the glomus tumor on the underlying phalanx may

induce bone erosion.		 It may also cause swelling. It may also be accompanied by distal phalanx fractures, nail avulsion, or finger-tip avulsions.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant has the following vascular lesion on her left cheek. The parents state it was not present at birth but had been growing rapidly for the first few weeks of life . What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-month child is brought to the hospital with noisy breathing since two weeks old. It gets worse when he is lying supine and gets relieved when the mother turns him to the prone position. The condition also aggravates on crying. Examination reveals inspiratory stridor. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. This increase in severity of inspiratory stridor in the supine position is associated with which of the following conditions?

A 43-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a nosebleed for the past 20 minutes. His medical history is consistent with hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. After a series of treatments, the bleeding does not stop. An endoscopy is ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in Kiesselbach's plexus. Which of the following is TRUE regarding anterior epistaxis?

questions.explanation:
Differences between Anterior and Posterior Epistaxis
  Anterior Epistaxis Posterior Epistaxis
Incidence Site More common Less common
Site Mostly from the little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Mostly from the posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity; often difficult to localize the bleeding point
Age Mostly occurs in children or young adults After 40 years of age
Cause Mostly trauma Spontaneous; often due to hypertension or arteriosclerosis
Bleeding Usually mild, it can be easily controlled by local pressure or anterior pack Bleeding is severe and requires hospitalization; a postnasal pack is often required

questions.text: A 9-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department due to a sore throat for 4 days. Physical examination reveals enlarged and congested tonsils . It is the 5

A 28-year-old male patient presents with a weak, breathy voice and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, there is unilateral vocal cord paralysis with the vocal cord in the intermediate position. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Larynx Summary

Location

Located in the neck, connecting the pharynx to the trachea, at the level of C3 to C6 vertebrae.

Structure

Composed of cartilage, muscles, and ligaments. Lined by a mucous membrane forming the epithelial lining of the vocal cords.

Nerve Supply

Provided by the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which has sensory and motor branches.

  • Sensory branches
    • Superior laryngeal nerve: Supplies sensation to laryngeal mucosa above the vocal cords.
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerves: Supplies sensation to laryngeal mucosa below the vocal cords.
  • Motor branches: Innervate intrinsic muscles of the larynx for vocal cord abduction and adduction.

 

Disease

Clinical Features

Important Points to Remember

Vocal Cord Paralysis

 

  • Hoarseness or weak/breathy voice
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Aspiration
  • Breathing difficulties
  • Reduced vocal cord movement on laryngoscopy

 

 

  • Vocal cord paralysis can result from various causes, such as nerve damage during surgery, trauma, viral infections, or neurological conditions.
  • Diagnosis involves laryngoscopy, imaging, and evaluation of vocal cord movement.
  • Management may include voice therapy, treatment of underlying cause, or surgical intervention depending on the severity and cause of paralysis.

 

Vocal Cord Nodules

 

  • Hoarseness
  • Breathiness
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Normal vocal cord movement on laryngoscopy
  • Benign growths on the vocal cords

 

 

  • Vocal cord nodules are often caused by vocal abuse/misuse, such as excessive shouting, talking loudly, or prolonged voice use.
  • Diagnosis involves laryngoscopy and voice evaluation.
  • Treatment may include voice therapy, vocal rest, and management of underlying vocal abuse.

Vocal Cord Polyps

 

  • Hoarseness
  • Breathiness
  • Changes in voice pitch/loudness
  • Fluid-filled lesions on the vocal cords

 

 

  • Vocal cord polyps are usually caused by vocal trauma, such as vocal abuse, vocal overuse, or vocal fold hemorrhage.
  • Diagnosis involves laryngoscopy and imaging.
  • Treatment may include voice therapy, vocal rest, and surgical removal of the polyps.

 

Laryngeal Cancer

 

  • Hoarseness
  • Pain or discomfort in the throat
  • Difficulty swallowing
  • Lymph node enlargement
  • Changes in voice quality
  • Malignant lesions in the larynx

 

 

  • Laryngeal cancer is often associated with risk factors such as smoking, alcohol use, and exposure to certain chemicals.
  • Diagnosis involves laryngoscopy, imaging, and biopsy.
  • Treatment may include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, or a combination depending on the stage and type of cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent episodes of acute laryngitis, with hoarseness of voice, cough, and throat discomfort. On laryngoscopy, bilateral redness and swelling of the vocal cords are seen, with no evidence of any mass lesions. Biopsy reveals no significant abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Location

Located in the larynx, specifically in the glottis, which is the middle part of the larynx.

 

Structure

Composed of stratified squamous epithelium, a protective layer covering the vocal cords.

Appearance

Vocal cords appear pearly white or pinkish in color, with well-defined edges.

Other Names

Vocal folds/ Vocal ligaments.

Disease

Clinical Features

1. Vocal Cord Nodules
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Vocal fatigue
  • Pain with voice use
  • Vocal pitch breaks
  • Vocal cords appear swollen and thickened on laryngoscopy

2. Vocal Cord Polyps
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Breathiness
  • Vocal pitch breaks
  • Unilateral or bilateral mass lesion on the vocal cord on laryngoscopy

 

3. Laryngeal Papilloma

 

  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Stridor
  • Dyspnea
  • Presence of wart-like growths on the vocal cords on laryngoscopy

4. Reinke's Edema
  • Deep, low-pitched voice
  • Vocal pitch breaks
  • Vocal cords appear swollen and fluid-filled on laryngoscopy

5. Laryngeal Cancer
  • Hoarseness of voice
  • Dysphagia
  • Pain with swallowing
  • Weight loss
  • Presence of mass lesion or ulceration on the vocal cords on laryngoscopy

questions.text: Which of the following is an expected response in a Normal Cold Spatula Test?

options.label: A
options.text: Blinking in response to the spatula.

questions.correct_answer: A. Blinking in response to the spatula.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A diagnostic procedure used to evaluate corneal sensitivity.

Who performs

Qualified healthcare professional, such as an ophthalmologist or optometrist.

Procedure

A cold spatula or chilled metal instrument is gently touched to the cornea, and the patient is instructed not to blink.

Purpose

To assess corneal sensation and identify abnormalities or damage to the corneal nerves.

Diseases Identified
  • Corneal infections
  • Neurotrophic keratitis
  • Corneal dystrophies
  • Other conditions associated with impaired corneal sensation

Findings and Outcomes

Normal response: Blinking in response to spatula, indicating intact corneal sensation. Abnormal response: No blinking or decreased blinking, indicating impaired corneal sensation.

Significance

Provides valuable information for diagnosis and management of ocular conditions related to corneal sensation.

Uses
  • As part of a comprehensive eye examination.
  • Evaluation of corneal sensation in patients with suspected corneal nerve damage or other ocular conditions.

Precautions
  • Should be performed by a qualified healthcare professional.
  • Proper aseptic techniques and hygiene should be followed to avoid the risk of infection.
  • Patients with eye conditions or history of eye surgery may require special consideration.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of severe right earache from the past two days. She is in her second trimester of pregnancy. There is no history of fever or upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, the right external ear appears red and swollen, with tenderness on palpation. The left ear is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Summary

Definition

Otalgia: Ear pain

Causes
  • Otitis media (infection of middle ear)
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • Meniere's disease (inner ear disorder)
  • Otitis externa (infection of external ear canal)
  • Other conditions such as temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders or referred pain from dental issues

Symptoms
  • Ear pain
  • Hearing loss
  • Vertigo
  • Fullness

Diagnosis

Clinical examination, otoscopy, audiometry, imaging studies may be needed

Treatment
  • Antibiotics for bacterial infections
  • Decongestants for Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • Lifestyle changes for Meniere's disease
  • Topical medications for otitis externa
  • Pain management as appropriate
  • Addressing underlying causes such as TMJ disorders or dental issues

Considerations

Pregnancy-related hormonal changes and vascularity may increase the risk of developing ear infections or exacerbate pre-existing conditions, safety of medications during pregnancy, consultation with qualified healthcare professional

Pathophysiology
  • Hormonal changes during pregnancy may affect the immune system, making pregnant individuals more susceptible to infections.
  • Increased vascularity and congestion in the upper respiratory tract and Eustachian tube may also contribute to ear-related symptoms

Prevention
  • Good ear hygiene
  • Avoiding triggers of otitis externa
  • Treating upper respiratory infections promptly
  • Addressing underlying conditions such as TMJ disorders or dental issues

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with hoarseness of voice and respiratory distress. On examination, multiple papillomatous lesions are visualized in the larynx and trachea. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Information

Definition

Rare benign condition characterized by recurrent papillomatous lesions in the larynx and respiratory tract

Age of Onset

Typically occurs in childhood, usually before the age of 5 years

Types
  • Early-Onset JORRP: Occurs in children before the age of 5 years
  • Late-Onset JORRP: Occurs in older children, adolescents, or adults after the age of 5 years

Clinical Features

Hoarse voice, recurrent cough, difficulty in breathing, respiratory distress

Causative Agent

Human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 6 and 11

Pathology

Papillomatous lesions in the larynx and other areas of the respiratory tract

Pathophysiology

HPV infection leads to abnormal proliferation of epithelial cells, causing papillomatous growths

Diagnosis

Visual examination of larynx and trachea, biopsy of lesions for histopathological confirmation

Treatment

Surgical excision (microdebrider, laser, or cold instrument excision), corticosteroids as adjunct

Prognosis

Recurrent nature of the disease, may require multiple surgeries, potential for airway compromise

Complications

Voice changes, respiratory distress, airway obstruction, risk of malignant transformation

Prevention

HPV vaccination, antiviral therapy in select cases

questions.text: The neural crest is a highly migratory multipotent cell population that forms at the interface between the neuroepithelium and the prospective epidermis of a developing embryo. They result in the formation of various structures within the eye. Which of the following is a neuroectodermal derivative?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Sphincter pu

Embryonic layers

Structures derived

Surface ectoderm
  • The crystalline lens
  • Epithelium of the cornea
  • Epithelium of the conjunctiva
  • Lacrimal gland
  • Epithelium of eyelids and its derivatives viz., cilia, tarsal glands, and conjunctival glands.
  • Epithelium lining the lacrimal apparatus.

Neural ectoderm
  • Retina with its pigment epithelium
  • Epithelial layers of the ciliary body
  • Epithelial layers of the iris
  • Sphincter and dilator pupillae muscles
  • Optic nerve (neuroglia and nervous elements only)
  • Melanocytes
  • Secondary vitreous
  • Ciliary zonules (tertiary vitreous)

Associated paraxial mesenchyme
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary vessels, central retinal artery, and other vessels are blood vessels.
  • Primary vitreous
  • Substantia propria, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium of the cornea
  • The sclera
  • Stroma of iris
  • Ciliary muscle
  • Sheaths of the optic nerve
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Fat, ligaments, and other connective tissue structures of the orbit

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with high blood sugar levels, worsening vision, patchy vision, and shapes floating in the area of vision, including dots and spots. On medical checkups of blood sugar levels and eyes through the compressive dilated exam, it became a general condition of diabetic retinopathy. What is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?

A 16-year-old male football player sustained an injury just above his right ear during a game. He developed a blurring of vision. He was able to see clearly with each eye. However, he experienced diplopia in both eyes, associated with worsening vision while looking downwards. His right eye was higher than his left in the primary position of gaze. Cranial nerve screening reveals a nerve palsy. Which of the following clinical feature can be seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Both eyes at the same position

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision in his left eye. He has a history of cataract surgery in the left eye 3 months ago. On examination, his visual acuity in the left eye is reduced markedly to hand movements. Slit-lamp examination shows an intraocular lens (IOL) in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Information
Definition Presence of an intraocular lens (IOL) in the eye after cataract surgery
Procedure Surgical removal of the cloudy lens (cataract) and replacement with an artificial lens
Types of IOLs
  • Monofocal IOLs: provide clear vision at a fixed distance (usually distance vision)
  • Multifocal IOLs: provide clear vision at different distances (near, intermediate, and distance)
  • Toric IOLs: correct astigmatism in addition to replacing the lens
Purpose Restore vision in patients with cataracts
Clinical Features Improved visual acuity, decreased glare, improved color perception
Characteristic Symptoms/ Findings
  • Clear vision at the intended distance (for monofocal IOLs)
  • Clear vision at different distances (for multifocal IOLs)
  • Corrected astigmatism (for toric IOLs)
Potential Complications Infection, inflammation, posterior capsular opacification, IOL dislocation
Follow-up Regular monitoring and management
Importance of regular follow-up Early detection and management of complications
Precautions Avoiding trauma to the eye, managing other ocular conditions
Management Close collaboration between ophthalmologist, optometrist, and patient

Disorder Definition Etiology Treatment
Post operative endophthalmitis Infection of vitreous cavity Post-op bacterial infection:
  • epidermidis
  • aureus
 DOC:
Intravitreal Vancomycin(for gram positive)
Intravitreal ceftazimide (for gram negative)
 
Cystoid Macular edema M/C cause of vision loss after cataract surgery Predisposing factors:
DM, uveitis, Vien occlusion, posterior capsular rupture
 		 Topical NSAID’s
Topical steroids
 
Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) Clouding of the posterior capsule of the lens, which can occur after cataract surgery Regrowth of lens epithelial cells YAG laser capsulotomy to create an opening in the clouded capsule

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought for a routine ophthalmic examination. The baby's eyes appear normal on external examination, but the red reflex test reveals a white reflex in one eye. The most likely refractive condition responsible for this finding is:
questions.explanation:
Refractive Condition Definition Etiology Risk Factors Clinical Features Diagnosis Management
Hyperopia Refractive error where the eye is shorter than normal or has a flatter cornea, resulting in difficulty seeing near objects. Genetic, environmental factors Family history, maternal diabetes, prematurity Blurred near vision, farsightedness, eye strain Cycloplegic refraction, visual acuity testing Correction with glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery
Myopia Refractive error where the eye is longer than normal or has a steeper cornea, resulting in difficulty seeing distant objects. Genetic, environmental factors Family history, prolonged near work, low outdoor exposure Blurred distant vision, nearsightedness Cycloplegic refraction, visual acuity testing Correction with glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery

 
Astigmatism		         
Refractive error where the cornea is irregularly shaped, resulting in distorted or blurred vision at all distances. 		  
Genetic, environmental factors 
Family history, corneal  scarring, eye trauma
Blurred or distorted vision, difficulty seeing fine details
Cycloplegic refraction, corneal topography
Correction with glasses, contact lenses, or refractive surgery

Anisometropia
Refractive error where there is a significant difference in the refractive power between the two eyes.
Genetic, environmental factors
Family history, intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity
Asymmetric vision, eye strain, amblyopia
Cycloplegic refraction, visual acuity testing
Correction with glasses,  contact lenses, or patching therapy for amblyopia

Cataracts 
Opacification of the lens of the eye, causing visual impairment.		 Genetic, environmental factors  
Maternal infections during pregnancy, genetic syndromes, metabolic disorders   
Cloudy or white pupil, poor visual fixation, nystagmus 
Ophthalmic examination, ultrasound of the eyes
Surgical removal of cataracts with intraocular lens  implantation

Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP)
Abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina of premature infants, leading to visual impairment.
 Prematurity, oxygen therapy,  other medical conditions
Low birth weight, prolonged oxygen therapy, prolonged hospitalization
Retinal vascular changes, retinal detachment, visual field defects
Ophthalmic examination, retinal imaging
Observation, laser therapy, cryotherapy, anti-VEGF injections

Congenital Glaucoma
Increased intraocular pressure due to maldevelopment of the eye's drainage system, leading to optic nerve damage and visual impairment.
Genetic factors, developmental anomalies
Family history, consanguinity, anterior segment dysgenesis
Enlarged cornea, tearing, photophobia, poor visual fixation
Ophthalmic examination, intraocular pressure measurement		  
Medical management, trabeculotomy, trabeculectomy

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with intermittent double vision and occasional eye squint. On examination, the child has well-aligned eyes and good visual acuity in both eyes. Stereopsis is reduced but present. Which grade of binocular vision does the child most likely have?
questions.explanation:
Grades of Binocular Vision Definition Clinical Features Management
Normal or Grade I Both eyes work together efficiently, providing clear and single vision with good stereopsis. Well-aligned eyes, full range of binocular vision functions, good depth perception. No specific management required. Regular eye care and follow-up.
Subnormal or Grade II Binocular vision is present but with reduced efficiency, leading to occasional diplopia or suppression. Mild misalignment, reduced stereopsis, occasional diplopia or suppression. May require vision therapy, prism glasses, or other interventions to improve binocular vision function.
Abnormal or Grade III Poor or no binocular vision, leading to constant diplopia, suppression, or amblyopia. Significant misalignment, no stereopsis, constant diplopia or suppression, possible amblyopia. Vision therapy, prism glasses, patching, and other interventions depending on the underlying cause.
Absent or Grade IV No binocular vision present, with one eye being functionally dominant while the other eye is suppressed. Total loss of binocular vision, one eye functionally dominant, the other eye suppressed. Management depends on the underlying cause and may involve vision therapy, patching, and other interventions.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic myopia comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. Examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. The gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. He has been prescribed a drug. At a follow-up examination several months later, intraocular pressure is normal, but the darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - L

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with complaints of pain, photophobia, and decreased vision in his left eye for the past 3 weeks. He has a history of using topical steroid. On examination, there is a large central corneal ulcer with irregular margins and a yellowish-white infiltrate. The anterior chamber is mildly inflamed, and there is a hypopyon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Information
Definition Fungal Keratitis is a corneal infection caused by fungal organisms, commonly Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Candida species.
Risk Factors
  • Contact lens wear
  • Ocular trauma (especially with organic matter)
  • Prolonged use of corticosteroid eye drops
  • Ocular surface diseases
  • Immunocompromised state
  • Poor hygiene
Clinical Features
  • Corneal ulcer with irregular margins
  • Yellowish-white infiltrate
  • Feathery or satellite lesions
  • Hypopyon (pus in the anterior chamber)
  • Severe pain, photophobia, and decreased vision
Diagnosis
  • Clinical examination, corneal scrapings for microbiological and histopathological examination, and fungal culture.
Types
  • Superficial (involving the epithelium and anterior stroma)
  • Deep (involving the deeper stroma and beyond)
Differential Diagnosis
  • Bacterial keratitis, viral keratitis, sterile corneal ulcer, and sterile infiltrates.
Treatment
  • Topical and/or systemic antifungal medications (e.g., natamycin, voriconazole, amphotericin B)
  • Frequent corneal debridement
  • Cycloplegic agents for pain relief
  • Management of associated risk factors
Complications
  • Corneal perforation
  • Vision loss
  • Endophthalmitis (infection of the intraocular contents)
  • Long-term corneal scarring leading to visual impairment
Prognosis
  • Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for favorable outcomes. Delayed or inadequate treatment may result in severe visual impairment or loss of the eye.
Prevention
  • Proper hygiene and care while handling contact lenses
  • Avoiding ocular trauma
  • Judicious use of corticosteroid eye drops
  • Regular follow-up for patients with risk factors
  • Patient education on ocular hygiene
Prophylaxis
  • In high-risk cases, prophylactic antifungal eye drops may be considered during corneal injuries or surgeries, especially in agricultural or tropical settings.

Aspect Fungal Keratitis Bacterial Keratitis Viral Keratitis
Causative Organisms Fungal organisms (e.g., Aspergillus, Fusarium, Candida) Bacterial organisms (e.g., Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, Pseudomonas) Viral organisms (e.g., Herpes simplex virus, Herpes zoster virus)
Risk Factors Contact lens wear, ocular trauma, corticosteroid use, immunocompromised state, poor hygiene Corneal injury/trauma, contact lens wear, ocular surface diseases, immunocompromised state Previous or concurrent viral infections, immunocompromised state
Clinical Features Corneal ulcer with irregular margins, yellowish-white infiltrate, feathery or satellite lesions, hypopyon, severe pain, photophobia, decreased vision Corneal ulcer with well-defined margins, purulent discharge, hypopyon, moderate pain, photophobia, decreased vision Corneal ulcer with characteristic branching dendritic or geographic pattern, foreign body sensation, tearing, redness
Diagnosis Clinical examination, corneal scrapings for microbiological and histopathological examination, fungal culture Clinical examination, corneal scrapings for microbiological examination (Gram stain, culture), bacterial culture and sensitivity Clinical examination, fluorescein staining (reveals dendritic or geographic pattern), viral culture, PCR
Treatment Topical and/or systemic antifungal medications, frequent corneal debridement, cycloplegic agents Topical and/or systemic antibiotics, frequent corneal debridement, cycloplegic agents Antiviral medications (topical and/or systemic), corticosteroids (in certain cases), lubricating eye drops
Complications Corneal perforation, vision loss, endophthalmitis, long-term corneal scarring Corneal perforation, vision loss, endophthalmitis, long-term corneal scarring Corneal scarring, corneal neovascularization, uveitis
Prognosis Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for favorable outcomes. Delayed or inadequate treatment may result in severe visual impairment or loss of the eye. Early diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for favorable outcomes. Delayed or inadequate treatment may result in severe visual impairment or loss of the eye. Prognosis depends on the type and severity of viral keratitis, with potential for recurrences and complications.
Treatment Duration Typically longer duration (weeks to months) Typically shorter duration (days to weeks) Typically variable duration (weeks to months)
Antiviral Medications Not effective Not effective Effective against specific viral organisms causing keratitis
Preventive Measures Proper hygiene and care while handling contact lenses, avoiding ocular trauma, judicious use of corticosteroid eye drops, regular follow-up for patients with risk factors, patient education Proper hygiene and care while handling contact lenses, avoiding ocular trauma, prompt treatment of corneal injuries, patient education Prevention and management of viral infections, patient education, antiviral prophylaxis in certain cases
