questions.text: An 85-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room by her son due to a penetrating stab injury on the anterior neck. A kitchen knife was deeply stuck in the midline of the anterior neck, but there was no active bleeding. The patient was semiconscious; bradycardia and hypotension were noted. Which of the following is the most likely reason?
What is the most common presenting symptom of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A rare, aggressive, undifferentiated carcinoma of the thyroid gland

Causes

Exact cause unknown, but may be related to genetic mutations, exposure to radiation, and history of previous thyroid malignancy

Symptoms

Rapidly growing neck mass, dysphagia, hoarseness, difficulty breathing, weight loss, fatigue

Pathophysiology

Poorly differentiated tumor with aggressive local invasion and distant metastasis

Diagnosis

Clinical assessment, imaging (ultrasound, CT, MRI), fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, histopathological examination; molecular testing for genetic mutations may be considered

Treatment

Multimodal approach with surgery (total thyroidectomy, neck dissection), radiotherapy, and chemotherapy; targeted therapies and immunotherapy may be considered in select cases; palliative care for advanced disease

Complications

Rapid disease progression, local invasion, distant metastasis, treatment-related complications (e.g., surgical complications, radiation toxicity)

Common Drugs

Chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin, doxorubicin, paclitaxel), targeted therapies (e.g., lenvatinib, sorafenib), immunotherapy (e.g., pembrolizumab)

Prognosis

Poor prognosis with high mortality rates; early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial for improving outcomes

Follow-up

Close monitoring for recurrence or metastasis, regular thyroid function tests, and imaging studies

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a lateral aberrant thyroid?

options.label: A
options.text: An ectopic thyroid gland located outside the normal thyroid bed

options.label: B
options.text: A thyroid nodule located on the lateral aspect of the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: An accessory thyroid gland located adjacent to the normal thyroid gland

options.label: D
options.text: A thyroid carcinoma with lateral extension beyond the thyroid capsule

questions.correct_answer: A. An ectopic thyroid gland located outside the normal thyroid bed
questions.explanation:
Category

Information

Definition

Lateral Aberrant Thyroid refers to the presence of ectopic thyroid tissue in the lateral neck region.

Causes

Developmental anomaly during embryogenesis, resulting in the abnormal migration of thyroid tissue to the lateral neck region.

Symptoms/ Clinical Features

Thyroid nodules or masses in the lateral neck region, swelling or discomfort, compression symptoms.

Pathophysiology

Ectopic thyroid tissue in the lateral neck region may have similar functioning as normal thyroid tissue, but its location outside the typical thyroid location may cause symptoms or complications.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Thyroid function tests, thyroid ultrasound, fine needle aspiration (FNA) or biopsy of the thyroid nodules/masses for further evaluation.

Treatment/ Management

Treatment depends on the size, location, and symptoms of the lateral aberrant thyroid. Options may include observation, thyroid hormone replacement therapy, surgical removal, or other interventions based on the individual case.

Complications

Compression symptoms, potential for malignancy in thyroid nodules, complications related to surgical intervention if performed.

Common Drugs with Doses Used

Levothyroxine for thyroid hormone replacement therapy, dosing based on individual patient requirements.

Prognosis

Prognosis depends on the size, location, and functional status of the lateral aberrant thyroid, as well as the presence of any associated complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Pendred Syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, goiter, and abnormal thyroid function tests

options.label: B
options.text: It is an X-linked dominant disorder characterized by the development of multiple osteochondromas

options.label: C
options.text: It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract

options.label: D
options.text: It is a type of neurofibromatosis characterized by the presence of multiple café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas

questions.correct_answer: A. It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, goiter, and abnormal thyroid function tests
questions.explanation:
Category

Information

Definition

Pendred Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.

Causes

Mutations in the SLC26A4 gene, which codes for a protein called pendrin, are the primary cause of Pendred Syndrome.

Symptoms/ Clinical Features

Sensorineural hearing loss, goiter or enlarged thyroid, speech and language delays, imbalance, tinnitus.

Pathophysiology

Mutations in the SLC26A4 gene lead to impaired iodide transport in the thyroid gland and inner ear, resulting in hearing loss and goiter.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Audiometric testing, thyroid function tests, thyroid ultrasound, genetic testing for SLC26A4 mutations.

Treatment/ Management

Hearing aids or cochlear implants for hearing loss, thyroid hormone replacement therapy for hypothyroidism, management of goiter symptoms.

Complications

Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter) can cause compression symptoms, speech and language delays may impact development.

Common Drugs with Doses Used

Levothyroxine for thyroid hormone replacement therapy, dosing based on individual patient requirements.

Prognosis

Prognosis varies depending on the severity of symptoms and early intervention. With appropriate management, many individuals with Pendred Syndrome can lead a relatively normal life.

Important Info

Genetic counseling and family screening are important for identifying carriers and providing appropriate management.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a palpable abdominal mass. CT scan shows a heterogeneous enhancing mass with calcifications. Biopsy confirms neuroblastoma. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

Childhood cancer that arises from developing nerve cells, typically in the adrenal glands or other parts of the sympathetic nervous system.

Causes
  • Unknown
  • Genetic mutations
  • Familial predisposition may play a role in some cases

Symptoms/Clinical Features

Varies widely depending on tumor location and size, but may include abdominal mass, pain, weight loss, fever, bone pain, and other nonspecific symptoms.

Pathophysiology

Abnormal growth of immature nerve cells, often resulting in a tumor that can spread to other parts of the body.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Imaging studies (e.g., CT, MRI, MIBG scan), biopsy, bone marrow aspiration/biopsy, urine and blood tests, genetic testing.

Treatment/ Management

Multimodal approach including surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, and targeted therapy; tailored to tumor risk stratification and patient age.

Complications

Metastasis, treatment-related side effects, long-term sequelae, and relapse.

Common Drugs with Doses Used
  • Chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., cisplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide)
  • Immunotherapeutic agents (e.g., dinutuximab, nivolumab)
  • Targeted therapy (e.g., crizotinib, lorlatinib).

Prognosis

Prognosis depends on tumor stage, age at diagnosis, and other factors; early detection and risk-based treatment can lead to favorable outcomes in some cases.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman underwent transsphenoidal surgery for a pituitary adenoma 5 years ago. She presents with a history of increasing headache, visual field defects, and increasing pigmentation of her skin. MRI reveals a pituitary mass measuring 3 cm. Laboratory studies show elevated ACTH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

A rare condition characterized by the enlargement of an adenoma or hyperplasia of the pituitary gland following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease.

Causes

Bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, which results in loss of adrenal cortisol feedback leading to pituitary gland hyperplasia or adenoma.

Symptoms/

Clinical Features

Manifestations may include hyperpigmentation, headache, visual disturbances, fatigue, weakness, menstrual irregularities, and signs of increased intracranial pressure.

Pathophysiology

Loss of cortisol feedback after bilateral adrenalectomy leads to overstimulation of the pituitary gland, resulting in hyperplasia or adenoma formation.

Diagnostic Findings/

Work Up

Imaging studies (e.g., MRI), hormone level measurements (e.g., ACTH, cortisol), and clinical evaluation to assess for signs and symptoms of pituitary gland enlargement.

Treatment/

Management

Treatment may involve medical management with somatostatin analogs, radiation therapy, or surgical intervention (e.g., transsphenoidal surgery) to manage symptoms and reduce tumor size.

Complications

Local compression effects due to pituitary gland enlargement, visual disturbances, hormonal imbalances, and recurrence or progression of the tumor.

Common Drugs

Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide, pasireotide) are commonly used for management

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with shortness of breath and cough. CT scan shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with sarcoidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

A chronic multisystem inflammatory disease that can affect any organ in the body, characterized by the formation of granulomas.

Causes

The exact cause of sarcoidosis is unknown, but it is thought to involve a complex interplay of genetic, environmental, and immune factors.

Symptoms/

Clinical Features

Manifestations vary widely depending on the organs involved and may include cough, dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, skin rashes, joint pain, eye inflammation, and other organ-specific symptoms.

Pathophysiology

The formation of granulomas, which are clusters of immune cells, in various organs results in inflammation and tissue damage. The exact pathophysiology is not fully understood.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation, medical history, physical examination, imaging studies (e.g., chest X-ray, CT scan), blood tests (e.g., ACE levels), and biopsy of affected organs to confirm granuloma formation.

Treatment/ Management

Treatment depends on the severity and organ involvement and may include observation, corticosteroids, immunosuppressive medications, and other organ-specific treatments. Regular monitoring and follow-up are important.

Complications

Complications may include organ damage, scarring, chronic inflammation, and related symptoms or complications specific to the affected organs.

Common Drugs
  • Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are commonly used for systemic sarcoidosis
  • Other immunosuppressive medications may also be used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with Frey's syndrome after a parotidectomy. Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Revision surgery to create a new flap

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Definition

Abnormal sweating and flushing on the face, neck, and scalp while eating or smelling food

Symptoms
  • Sweating and flushing on the face, neck, and scalp 
  • Triggered by gustatory stimuli (e.g., eating or smelling food) 
  • Localized to the affected area

Causes
  • Damage to parotid gland during surgery 
  • Trauma or injury to the auriculotemporal nerve 
  • Abnormal nerve regeneration

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history and physical examination 
  • Minor's starch-iodine test 
  • Quantitative sudomotor axon reflex test (QSART) 
  • Imaging tests (e.g., MRI) to rule out other causes

Treatment
  • Conservative measures (e.g., avoiding trigger foods) 
  • Topical antiperspirants or anticholinergic medications 
  • Botulinum toxin injections 
  • Surgical interventions (rarely used)

Prognosis
  • Chronic condition that may persist for life 
  • Symptoms can be managed with treatment 
  • Relatively benign and not life-threatening

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of swelling and pain in his left leg, which has been worsening for the past few months. On examination, the patient is found to have varicose veins in his left leg, with significant swelling and discoloration of the skin. Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Referral to a vascular surgeon for varicose vein surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical intervention with vein ligation and stripping

questions.correct_answer: A. Immediate anticoagulation therapy with heparin
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

Dilated, tortuous veins that commonly occur in the legs due to dysfunctional valves and weakened vein walls.

Causes

Weak valves and vein walls, age, family history, pregnancy, obesity, prolonged sitting or standing.

Symptoms/

Clinical Features

Visible swollen veins, pain, heaviness, cramping, itching, skin changes in affected areas.

Pathophysiology

Weak or damaged valves in veins cause blood pooling, leading to vein dilation and tortuosity.

Diagnostic Findings/

Work Up

Clinical evaluation, medical history, physical examination, imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound).

Treatment/

Management

Conservative measures (compression stockings, lifestyle changes), medical and minimally invasive interventions (endovenous ablation, sclerotherapy, phlebectomy) for symptomatic/severe cases.

Complications

Pain, discomfort, skin changes, venous ulcers, superficial thrombophlebitis.

Common Drugs

Pain relief medications (e.g., NSAIDs) for symptom management.

Prognosis

Generally good with appropriate management. Early intervention and lifestyle changes can help alleviate symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male smoker presents with a 2-year history of progressive pain and numbness in his left leg. On physical examination, he has absent pulses in the left foot and calf, and decreased hair growth on the left leg. Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Angioplasty of the left popliteal artery

options.label: B
options.text: Below-knee amputation of the left leg

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Also known as Buerger's disease, it is a non-atherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disorder that affects small- and medium-sized arteries and veins, primarily in the extremities.

Causes

Unknown, but associated with heavy tobacco use and genetic factors.

Symptoms/

Clinical Features

Pain, tenderness, inflammation, and ulcers in the extremities, especially in the hands and feet.

Pathophysiology

Inflammatory process leads to thrombosis and occlusion of small and medium-sized arteries and veins, resulting in reduced blood flow and tissue damage.

Diagnostic Findings/

Work Up

Clinical evaluation, medical history, physical examination, imaging studies (e.g., angiography), exclusion of other causes of vascular disease.

Treatment/

Management

Smoking cessation, lifestyle changes, antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications, symptomatic relief, and sometimes surgical interventions (e.g., bypass surgery).

Complications

Tissue necrosis, gangrene, amputation, and potential for recurrence despite treatment.

Common Drugs

Smoking cessation aids (e.g., nicotine replacement therapy) for tobacco cessation. Antiplatelet or anticoagulant medications (e.g., aspirin, heparin) for symptom management.

Prognosis

Variable, depends on the stage of the disease and adherence to treatment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a pulsatile mass in his left wrist that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On examination, there is a prominent thrill and bruit over the mass. Doppler ultrasound reveals a high flow arteriovenous fistula. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical ligation and excision of the fistula

questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical ligation and excision of the fistula
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

An abnormal connection between an artery and a vein, usually resulting from trauma, surgery, or congenital malformation.

Causes

Trauma, iatrogenic (e.g., surgical procedures, catheterization), congenital (e.g., vascular malformations).

Symptoms/ Clinical Features

Pulsatile mass, thrill or bruit (audible sound), warmth, swelling, and sometimes pain at the site of the fistula.

Pathophysiology

Abnormal connection between an artery and vein results in shunting of blood, leading to increased blood flow, pressure, and volume in the vein, and potential downstream effects on surrounding tissues and organs.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Clinical evaluation, medical history, physical examination, imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, angiography) to confirm the presence and location of the fistula.

Treatment/ Management

Management depends on the location, size, and symptoms of the fistula. Options include observation, embolization (closure of the fistula using endovascular techniques), or surgical repair.

Complications

Bleeding, infection, thrombosis, congestive heart failure, tissue damage, and potential for recurrence after treatment.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing ulcer on the right lower leg that has been present for several years. Biopsy of the ulcer reveals squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide local excision with 1 cm margins

options.label: C
options.text: Amputation of the right lower leg

questions.correct_answer: A. Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

A malignant transformation of a chronic non-healing wound, scar, or burn site into a squamous cell carcinoma.

Causes

Prolonged inflammation, chronic non-healing wounds, scars, or burns, previous trauma or injury to the skin, genetic predisposition, exposure to environmental carcinogens.

Symptoms/ Clinical Features

Ulceration or nodular growth at the site of a chronic wound, scar, or burn, with potential for pain, bleeding, discharge, and local tissue destruction.

Pathophysiology

Malignant transformation of chronically inflamed or damaged skin tissue into squamous cell carcinoma due to genetic mutations and cellular changes.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up

Clinical evaluation, medical history, physical examination, biopsy of the lesion to confirm the presence of squamous cell carcinoma.

Treatment/ Management

Surgical excision of the lesion with appropriate margins, potential use of radiation therapy or chemotherapy in advanced cases.

Complications

Local tissue destruction, potential for metastasis (spread) to nearby lymph nodes or distant organs, recurrence after treatment.

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of aortic stenosis and recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. Upon further investigation, he is found to have severe von Willebrand disease. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing his recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Topic

Summary

Definition

Heyde's syndrome refers to the association between aortic stenosis and gastrointestinal bleeding due to acquired Von Willebrand syndrome.

Causes

Aortic stenosis (narrowing of the aortic valve), acquired Von Willebrand syndrome (deficiency or dysfunction of Von Willebrand factor), potential genetic and environmental factors.

Symptoms/ Clinical Features

Gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, fatigue, weakness, heart-related symptoms such as chest pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath due to aortic stenosis.

Pathophysiology

The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is thought that high shear stress across the diseased aortic valve leads to acquired Von Willebrand syndrome, which in turn can cause bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnostic Findings/ Work Up
  • Clinical evaluation
  • Medical history
  • Physical examination
  • Blood tests to assess von Willebrand factor levels and activity
  • Echocardiography to confirm aortic stenosis

Treatment/ Management
  • Management of aortic stenosis, which may include medical therapy, balloon valvuloplasty, or valve replacement surgery.
  • Treatment of underlying gastrointestinal bleeding, including endoscopic procedures, blood transfusions, and correction of Von Willebrand factor deficiency.

Complications

Severe bleeding episodes, anemia, heart-related complications due to aortic stenosis, potential need for surgical intervention for both aortic stenosis and gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 79-year-man is brought to the emergency department after feeling lightheadedness and palpitation. Her examination shows scattered purpura. She has not traveled anywhere recently and has not acquired any infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Physical examination reveals a palpable liver and spleen. Her lab findings include haemoglobin 7.5 g/dl, MCV – 70 fL, RDW – 22 and decreased osmotic fragility . The peripheral smear reveals golf ball inclusion bodies . What is the probable diagnosis in this case?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of pale-coloured skin, bruising, shortness of breath, and extreme fatigue . He also has a history of several episodes of bony pain . On examination, he is found with splenomegaly . His blood picture denotes a variable number of immature cells of the myeloid series and nucleated red cells in circulation. This blood picture may not be seen in which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Infections Fungal, HIV etc.
Tumours

Metastatic carcinomas.

Lymphomas, e.g., Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Leukemias, e.g., CML, AML, Hairy cell leukaemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with 7 kg weight loss, flatulence and occasional episodes of non-bloody diarrhoea for the past year. On physical examination, he appears thin and pale. Her blood pressure is 100/75 mmHg, pulse is 65 beats/min, and BMI is 17 kg/m². Laboratory investigation showed low serum iron and folate levels . Gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed villous atrophy and positive IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody . Which of the following is the most critical complication of this disease?
questions.explanation:
Celiac disease

Aetiology
  • Autoimmune reaction against gliadin (gluten-protein)
  • Genetic predisposition in HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases

Clinical findings
  • Chronic diarrhoea
  • Steatorrhea
  • Flatulence
  • Bloating
  • Abdominal pain

Extraintestinal

manifestations
  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Peripheral neuropathies
  • Neuropsychiatric problems

Diagnostic tests
  • Antibodies
  • IgA Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • IgA Anti-endomysial antibodies
  • Confirmatory test: Duodenal biopsy
  • Atrophy of villi
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes

Treatment
  • Life-long gluten-free diet
  • Iron, calcium, and vitamin D supplements
  • Dapsone for dermatitis herpetiformis

Complications
  • Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma
  • Ulcerative jejunitis

Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the patient’s condition?

She was again found to be hypertensive and was prescribed hydralazine, a β-blocker, and furosemide. The woman takes no additional prescription or over-the-counter medications. The physician orders an autoantibody panel: Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): Positive Anti-histone antibodies: Positive What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with type 2 diabetes presents with elevated fasting blood glucose levels despite adequate glycemic control throughout the day. His bedtime glucose levels are normal, but his fasting glucose levels are consistently elevated. What is the most likely cause of this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

   

Summary

Definition

Dawn Phenomenon is a phenomenon observed in diabetes where there is an early morning increase in blood glucose levels.

Causes

Insulin resistance, decreased insulin sensitivity, increased hepatic glucose production.

Symptoms

Increased blood glucose levels in the early morning, frequent urination, increased thirst.

Clinical Features

Hyperglycemia, polyuria, polydipsia, increased appetite, fatigue.

Pathophysiology

The Dawn Phenomenon is thought to be related to hormonal changes during the early morning hours, including increased secretion of growth hormone, cortisol, and glucagon, leading to increased hepatic glucose production.

Diagnostic Findings

Fasting blood glucose levels checked in the early morning hours (between 2 a.m. and 8 a.m.) consistently above the target range.

Work Up

Fasting blood glucose monitoring, HbA1c levels, glucose tolerance test, continuous glucose monitoring.

Treatment/ Management

Adjusting the timing and/or dose of anti-diabetic medications, increasing physical activity, dietary modifications, optimizing diabetes management plan with healthcare provider.

Complications

Uncontrolled hyperglycemia, increased risk of long-term complications of diabetes, such as neuropathy, retinopathy, nephropathy, cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with worsening proteinuria and declining renal function. He also has hypertension and peripheral edema. Renal biopsy reveals thickened glomerular basement membrane with diffuse mesangial expansion and nodular glomerulosclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

   

Summary

Definition

Diabetic Nephropathy is a progressive kidney disease that occurs as a complication of diabetes mellitus.

Causes

Prolonged uncontrolled hyperglycemia, high blood pressure, genetic predisposition, oxidative stress, inflammation.

Symptoms

Early stages may be asymptomatic. Later stages may include proteinuria (excessive protein in urine), edema (swelling), hypertension, fatigue, frequent urination.

Clinical Features

Progressive decline in kidney function, persistent proteinuria, hypertension, edema, electrolyte imbalances, signs of uremia (nausea, vomiting, anorexia, pruritus).

Pathophysiology

Chronic hyperglycemia leads to increased oxidative stress, inflammation, and damage to the blood vessels in the kidneys, resulting in glomerular basement membrane thickening, mesangial expansion, and progressive renal damage.

Diagnostic Findings

Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR), blood glucose levels, blood pressure monitoring, renal ultrasound.

Work Up

Regular monitoring of blood glucose levels, blood pressure control, lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise), medications to manage hypertension and hyperglycemia, referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management.

Treatment/

Management

Blood glucose control, blood pressure control, lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise), use of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitors (e.g., ACE inhibitors, ARBs), management of complications (e.g., anemia, electrolyte imbalances), referral to a nephrologist for specialized care.

Complications

Progression to end-stage renal disease (ESRD), cardiovascular disease, anemia, electrolyte imbalances, bone disorders.

Common Drugs with Doses Used
  • ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril, lisinopril), ARBs (e.g., losartan, irbesartan)
  • Diuretics (e.g., furosemide)
  • Antihypertensive medications (e.g., amlodipine, metoprolol)
  • Insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents as per individualized treatment plan.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with resistant hypertension, muscle weakness, and polyuria. On laboratory evaluation, he has hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and an elevated aldosterone to renin ratio. Imaging studies reveal adrenal adenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical removal of the adrenal adenoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Surgical removal of the adrenal adenoma
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Conn syndrome is a condition characterized by overproduction of aldosterone, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands that regulates electrolyte balance, leading to excessive retention of sodium and loss of potassium.

Causes
  • Aldosterone-producing adenoma (Conn's adenoma)
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • Familial hyperaldosteronism

Types
  • Unilateral aldosterone-producing adenoma
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (multifocal)
  • Familial hyperaldosteronism (genetic)

Symptoms
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia (low potassium levels)
  • Weakness
  • Muscle cramps
  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia

Clinical Features
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Muscle weakness
  • Cardiac manifestations

Pathophysiology
  • Increased aldosterone production
  • Excessive retention of sodium
  • Loss of potassium

Diagnostic Findings
  • Serum aldosterone-to-renin ratio
  • Plasma aldosterone concentration
  • Imaging studies (CT, MRI)

Workup
  • Serum electrolyte levels
  • Renin and aldosterone levels
  • Imaging studies

Treatment/

Management
  • Surgical removal of aldosterone-producing adenoma (if applicable)
  • Medications (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone)
  • Lifestyle modifications
  • Regular monitoring

Complications
  • Hypertension-related complications
  • Hypokalemia-related complications

Common Drugs with Doses Used
  • Spironolactone (25-400 mg/day)
  • Eplerenone (25-200 mg/day)
  • Amiloride (5-20 mg/day)
  • Triamterene (50-100 mg/day)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with uncontrolled hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. She has no significant past medical history and is not taking any medications. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and laboratory investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 2.8 mEq/L, serum sodium level of 142 mEq/L, and arterial blood gas (ABG) showing pH of 7.48 and bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 30 mEq/L. Her plasma renin activity (PRA) is low, and plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A condition characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands, leading to increased sodium retention and potassium excretion, resulting in hypertension and electrolyte imbalances.

Causes
  • Adrenal adenoma (Benign tumor of the adrenal gland)
  • Adrenal hyperplasia (Enlargement of the adrenal glands)
  • Adrenal carcinoma (Malignant tumor of the adrenal gland)

Types
  • Unilateral (aldosterone-producing adenoma, APA)
  • Bilateral (idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia, IHA)

Symptoms/

Clinical features
  • Hypertension (high blood pressure)
  • Hypokalemia (low blood potassium levels)
  • Muscle weakness and cramps
  • Polyuria (increased urine production)
  • Polydipsia (increased thirst)
  • Fatigue
  • Headache

Pathophysiology
  • Increased production of aldosterone, a hormone that regulates salt and water balance, by the adrenal glands
  • Leads to increased sodium retention and potassium excretion, resulting in increased blood volume and hypertension

Diagnostic findings/ Work Up
  • Serum aldosterone to renin ratio (ARR) elevated
  • Confirmation tests like saline infusion test or fludrocortisone suppression test
  • Imaging studies (CT/MRI) to identify adrenal adenoma or hyperplasia

Treatment/ Management
  • Surgical removal of adenoma (APA) or unilateral adrenal gland (if caused by adrenal carcinoma)
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (e.g. spironolactone, eplerenone) for bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (IHA)
  • Lifestyle modifications (e.g. low-sodium diet)

Complications
  • Hypertension-related complications (e.g. stroke, heart attack, heart failure)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (e.g. hypokalemia)
  • Adverse effects of medications (e.g. hyperkalemia with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists)

Common Drugs with doses Used
  • Spironolactone (25-200 mg/day)
  • Eplerenone (25-100 mg/day)
  • Amiloride (5-20 mg/day)

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is measured by esophageal manometry?

options.label: A
options.text: Pressure changes in the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.explanation:
Aspect

   

Summary

Definition

Esophageal manometry is a diagnostic procedure used to assess the motility and function of the esophagus, measuring the pressure and coordination of esophageal contractions.

Types
  • High-resolution manometry (HRM): Uses a catheter with closely spaced pressure sensors to provide detailed information about esophageal motility
  • Conventional manometry: Uses a catheter with fewer pressure sensors

Diagnostic findings/ Work Up
  • Measures pressure changes in the esophagus during swallowing and at rest
  • Can identify conditions such as achalasia, esophageal spasms, and other motility disorders

Complications
  • Minimal risks, such as minor discomfort or irritation from the catheter
  • Rarely, perforation or bleeding (very rare)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain localized in the left lower quadrant, along with fever and nausea. He has a history of constipation and occasional episodes of abdominal discomfort in the past. On physical examination, there is tenderness and guarding over the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory tests show an elevated white blood cell count. CT scan of the abdomen reveals thickening of the sigmoid colon wall with pericolic fat stranding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

Diverticulitis is an inflammatory condition that affects the diverticula, small pouches that form in the lining of the colon, causing pain and discomfort.

Causes
  • Low-fiber diet
  • Aging 
  • Constipation 
  • Obesity 
  • Genetics

Types

Diverticulitis is a single condition, but can be classified into uncomplicated or complicated based on severity

Symptoms/ Clinical features
  • Abdominal pain (often left lower quadrant) 
  • Fever 
  • Nausea and vomiting 
  • Change in bowel habits 
  • Tenderness or palpable mass in the abdomen 
  • Bleeding (rare)

Pathophysiology
  • Increased pressure in the colon leads to the formation of diverticula 
  • Fecal matter and bacteria can get trapped in diverticula, leading to inflammation and infection

Diagnostic findings/ Work Up
  • Physical examination 
  • Imaging studies (e.g. CT scan of the abdomen) 
  • Blood tests (e.g. complete blood count, inflammatory markers)

Treatment/ Management
  • Mild cases: Clear liquid diet, oral antibiotics, pain management 
  • Severe cases: Hospitalization, intravenous antibiotics, bowel rest, possible surgical intervention 
  • Prevention: High-fiber diet, increased fluid intake, regular bowel movements

Complications
  • - Abscess formation 
  • Fistula formation 
  • Bowel obstruction 
  • Perforation 
  • Sepsis

Common Drugs with doses Used
  • Antibiotics (e.g. ciprofloxacin, metronidazole) as per clinician's discretion and severity of infection 
  • Pain management (e.g. acetaminophen, ibuprofen) as per clinician's discretion and severity of pain

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a long-standing history of dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a dilated esophagus with multiple rings and furrows, resembling a "stack of coins" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Summary

Definition

A congenital condition in which the smooth muscle of the lower esophagus is replaced by striated muscle

Causes

Genetic mutation during embryonic development

Symptoms

Dysphagia, regurgitation, vomiting, weight loss, coughing

Pathophysiology

Abnormal development of the esophageal smooth muscle, resulting in abnormal motility

Diagnosis

Clinical signs, imaging studies (e.g., barium swallow), endoscopy, biopsy

Treatment

Symptomatic management (e.g., soft food, frequent small meals, elevation of food bowl), possible surgical intervention

Complications

Esophageal stricture, aspiration pneumonia, malnutrition

Common Drugs

Symptomatic management only, no specific drugs

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Echocardiography reveals a narrowed aortic valve orifice with increased velocity of blood flow across the valve. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspects

Summary

Definition

Narrowing of the aortic valve orifice, obstructing blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta

Causes

Congenital (most common), acquired (calcific aortic stenosis in older adults)

Types

Congenital, acquired (calcific)

Symptoms

Chest pain, syncope, fatigue, dyspnea, heart murmur, palpitations

Pathophysiology

Thickening and stiffening of the aortic valve leaflets, reducing valve opening and obstructing blood flow

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation, echocardiography, electrocardiography, chest X-ray, cardiac catheterization

Treatment

Symptomatic management, medication (e.g., beta blockers, calcium channel blockers), balloon valvuloplasty, surgical valve replacement

Complications

Left ventricular hypertrophy, heart failure, arrhythmias, infective endocarditis

Common Drugs

Beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil)

Doses Used

Dose depends on patient age, weight, and severity of symptoms, consult a cardiologist for appropriate dosing

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents to the physician for grossly irregular cycles. Her cycle length varies from 20 to 40 days and she is unable to plan her long distance travels due to uncertainty of her period dates. All of the following can be used to determine the phase of menstrual cycle in such a patient, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Method Description
Menstrual Calendar Tracking the start and end dates of menstruation on a calendar to estimate the follicular and luteal phases.
Basal Body Temperature (BBT) Measuring body temperature every morning before getting out of bed to detect the subtle rise after ovulation (luteal phase).
Cervical Mucus Observation Monitoring changes in cervical mucus consistency and volume to identify fertile days and the transition to the luteal phase.
Ovulation Predictor Kits Using urine or saliva tests to detect the surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) that occurs just before ovulation.
Hormone Blood Tests Measuring hormone levels (e.g., estrogen, progesterone, LH, FSH) at specific times to pinpoint the phase of the menstrual cycle.
Ultrasound Visualizing the ovaries and observing the presence of follicles or the corpus luteum to assess the follicular or luteal phase.
Endometrial Biopsy Collecting a sample of the uterine lining to evaluate its characteristics and determine the phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with irregular menstrual cycles and anemia is diagnosed to have polymenorrhagia. The menstrual abnormality in the girl is?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in frequency of cycle along with excessive or prolonged bleeding

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in frequency of cycle along with excessive or prolonged bleeding

questions.text: When planning ART (Artificial Reproductive Techniques) cycles for couples, which factor is not a concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?

A 25-year-old woman presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of a painful menstrual cycle. She further complains that she has raised her body temperature during this period. There are no abnormalities on physical examination. In a woman of reproductive age group with regular menstrual cycles and documented ovulation, which of the following event occurs during the ovulation phase?

options.label: B
options.text: FSH induced steroidogenesis in granulosa cells

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulation of the arrested meiotic division of the oocyte

questions.correct_answer: D. Stimulation of the arrested meiotic division of the oocyte
questions.explanation:
Menstrual Cycle Phase Description
Menstrual Phase (Day 1-5) The menstrual phase marks the beginning of the cycle. During this phase, the endometrial lining of the uterus sheds, leading to menstrual bleeding. This phase typically lasts for 3 to 5 days.
Follicular Phase (Day 1-13) The follicular phase follows the menstrual phase. It is characterized by the growth and development of ovarian follicles in response to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the pituitary gland. One of the follicles becomes dominant, and it releases increasing amounts of estrogen. This phase ends with ovulation.
Ovulation Phase (Day 14) Ovulation is a brief phase during which the matured dominant follicle ruptures, releasing a secondary oocyte (immature egg) into the fallopian tube. This phase is triggered by a surge in luteinizing hormone (LH) from the pituitary gland. The ovulation phase occurs around day 14 of a 28-day cycle but may vary in different individuals.
Luteal Phase (Day 15-28) The luteal phase begins after ovulation and is characterized by the formation of the corpus luteum from the ruptured follicle. The corpus luteum produces progesterone and some estrogen to prepare the uterine lining for possible implantation of a fertilized egg. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates, and progesterone levels decline, leading to the start of a new menstrual cycle.

She has 4 live children with one abortion. Also, she was concerned about limiting her family from having no contraindications for oral contraceptive pills. questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the OPD for her first prenatal check-up at 8 weeks of gestation . She has had a history of nodular cystic acne for 2 years for which she had been taking an oral drug prescribed by her dermatologist. The drug used by the patient is a category X drug . Which of the following drugs is the patient most likely taking ?
questions.explanation:
United States FDA Pharmaceutical Pregnancy Categories

Category A

Adequate and well-controlled human studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy (and there is no evidence of risk in later trimesters).

Category B

Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women OR Animal studies have shown an adverse effect, but adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in any trimester.

Category C

Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Category D

There is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience or studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Category X

Studies in animals or humans have demonstrated fetal abnormalities and/or there is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience and the risks involved in use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweigh potential benefits.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for converting androgens to estrogens in the ovarian follicle?
questions.explanation:
Site of Steroidogenesis Ovary
Major Hormones Produced Estrogen, Progesterone, Androgens
Major Cells Involved Theca and Granulosa Cells
Stimulating Hormones Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
Process Theca cells convert cholesterol into androgens, which are then converted by granulosa cells into estrogens
Major Estrogens Produced Estradiol, Estrone, Estriol
Major Progesterone Produced Progesterone
Feedback Mechanisms Negative Feedback (estrogen and progesterone) and Positive Feedback (LH surge)
Regulation Regulated by hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a rare congenital disorder that affects the female reproductive system and is characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina?
questions.correct_answer: C. Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser (MRKH) syndrome
questions.explanation:
Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser (MRHK) syndrome
Definition
  • Rare congenital disorder affecting female reproductive system
Symptoms
  • Absence or underdevelopment of uterus and upper two-thirds of vagina
  • Normal external genitalia and functioning ovaries
Diagnosis
  • Pelvic examination
  • Ultrasound or MRI
  • Blood tests may be done to check hormone levels and rule out other conditions
Treatment
  • Creation of neovagina and potential reconstruction of uterus through surgical or non-surgical methods
  • Neovaginoplasty is the most common surgical treatment
  • Uterine reconstruction may involve the use of a gestational carrier or surrogate to carry a pregnancy
Genetic counseling
  • Recommended for individuals with MRKH syndrome and their families
  • Counseling can provide information about the inheritance pattern of MRKH syndrome and the potential risks of passing the disorder on to future generations

questions.text: Which among the following is the true statement about the distribution given in the figure below?

A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency room with a deep laceration on his foot sustained while working in his garden. The wound is dirty and the patient reports that he has not received a tetanus shot in over 10 years. The healthcare provider decides to administer tetanus prophylaxis. Which of the following options is the best choice for tetanus prophylaxis in this patient?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: Tetanus immune globulin (TIG) followed by tetanus toxoid vaccine

questions.explanation:
Type of Vaccine Indications
Tetanus toxoid (TT)
  • Routine booster for adults every 10 years.
Tetanus toxoid, reduced diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine (Tdap)

  • Also recommended for pregnant women during each pregnancy.
Tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td)
  • Routine booster for adults every 10 years.
Tetanus toxoid 
Reduced diphtheria toxoid
Inactivated poliovirus vaccine (Tdap-IPV)
 
  • For adults who require protection against tetanus, diphtheria, and polio.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, weight loss, and a persistent cough. On further questioning, he admits to have multiple sexual partners and having used intravenous drugs in the past. Laboratory testing reveals a low CD4 count. Which of the following statements regarding the epidemiology of this disease is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of this infection worldwide occur through heterosexual transmission.

options.label: B
options.text: The incidence of this disease is decreasing in all age groups in the United States.

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous drug use is the primary mode of transmission for this disease in sub-Saharan Africa.

options.label: D
options.text: It disproportionately affects men who have sex with men in high-income countries.

questions.correct_answer: A. The majority of this infection worldwide occur through heterosexual transmission.
questions.explanation:
Modes of Transmission Associated Risk Factors
Sexual Contact (unprotected) Multiple sexual partners, having another sexually transmitted infection, receptive anal intercourse
Injection drug use (sharing needles) Sharing of needles, syringes, or other injectable equipment
Perinatal transmission (from mother to child) Untreated HIV infection during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding
Occupational exposure (healthcare workers) Accidental needle-stick injuries or exposure to infected blood or bodily fluids
Blood transfusion or organ transplantation Receipt of blood or organs from an infected donor
Non-sterilized medical equipment Reusing or improperly sterilizing medical equipment

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine types provide the longest duration of protection?
questions.correct_answer: C. Subunit, recombinant, or conjugate vaccines
questions.explanation:
Vaccine Type Mechanism of Action
Live attenuated
  • Uses a weakened form of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response. 
  • Examples 
    • MMR
    • Varicella
    • Yellow fever vaccines.
Inactivated
  • Uses a killed form of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response. 
  • Examples 
    • Polio
    • hepatitis A
    • Rabies vaccines.
Subunit, recombinant, or conjugate
  • Uses only specific parts of the virus or bacteria to stimulate an immune response. 
  • Examples  
    • HPV
    • Pneumococcal
    • Meningococcal vaccines.
mRNA
  • Uses a small piece of genetic material to instruct cells to produce a protein that triggers an immune response. 
  • Examples 
    • COVID-19 vaccines developed by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna.
Vector
  • Uses a harmless virus or bacteria to deliver genetic material that instructs cells to produce a protein that triggers an immune response. 
  • Examples
    • COVID-19 vaccines developed by AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.

questions.text: A large-scale study is conducted to determine the occurrence of a disease in a particular population over a five-year period. At the beginning of the study, there were 1,000 individuals in the population who were free of the disease. After five years, 100 new cases of the disease were diagnosed. What is the incidence rate of the disease in this population over the five-year period?
questions.explanation:
Incidence Prevalence
Definition The number of new cases of a disease in a population during a specific time period. The total number of cases of a disease in a population at a specific time point.
Calculation Number of new cases / Population at risk Number of cases / Total population
Time frame Refers to a specific time period. Refers to a specific point in time.

Interpretation  
Measures the risk of developing a disease.
Measures the burden of disease in a population.

Factors affecting value
Duration of the disease, incidence rate, and population at risk.
Duration of the disease, prevalence rate, and population at risk.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a pruritic rash and fever. The rash started on his face and spreads to his trunk and extremities. On examination, you notice multiple papules and vesicles with an erythematous base. The patient reports feeling unwell and has not been vaccinated against this disease. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Criteria Summary
Epidemiology Common childhood infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Can affect adults who have not been previously infected or vaccinated.
Transmission Spread through respiratory droplets or contact with fluid from blisters of infected individuals. Highly contagious.
Symptoms Fever, headache, tiredness, and an itchy rash that starts on the face, chest, and back and spreads to the rest of the body. Blisters may appear and eventually scab over.
Treatment Most cases resolve without treatment, but antiviral medications may be prescribed for severe cases or high-risk individuals. 
Calamine lotion, oatmeal baths, and antihistamines can help relieve itching. Vaccination is available for prevention.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the National Nutrition Mission/POSHAN Abhiyaan?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the prevalence of stunting, under-nutrition, anemia, and low birth weight

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the overall food production in the country

options.label: C
options.text: To provide financial assistance to the farmers for the cultivation of nutritious crops

options.label: D
options.text: To establish more hospitals and health centers across the country

questions.correct_answer: A. To reduce the prevalence of stunting, under-nutrition, anemia, and low birth weight
questions.explanation:
Objectives Components Strategies
Reduce stunting
  • Improving maternal and adolescent nutrition
  • Infant and young child feeding practices
  • Promoting early initiation of breastfeeding
  • Exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months
  • Introducing age-appropriate complementary feeding
  • Nutrition and health education for mothers and caregivers
  • Growth monitoring and promotion
  • Supplementation with vitamins and minerals
  • Access to clean drinking water and sanitation facilities
Reduce wasting
  • Management of SAM and MAM cases
  • Community-based management of acute malnutrition
  • Provision of therapeutic foods
  • Micronutrient supplementation
  • Follow-up care and support
Improve anemia
  • Supplementation with iron and folic acid
  • Weekly iron-folic acid supplementation for women
  • Iron and folic acid supplementation for children
  • Deworming interventions
Improve health
  • Improving access to quality health services and hygiene
  • Immunization against major childhood diseases
  • Preventing and treating common childhood illnesses
  • Provision of safe drinking water and sanitation
  • Behavior change communication
